channel.title: .htaccess and could it be used in a server?
channel.description:
Goal: block all vpn, proxy and tor traffic from accessing server/site
Could someone explain this snippet of code that I found which supposedly does the trick? And not a summary of what it does. I'd like to know what individual characters and directives mean.
[code] RewriteEngine on RewriteCond %{HTTP:VIA} !^$ [OR] RewriteCond %{HTTP:FORWARDED} !^$ [OR] RewriteCond %{HTTP:USERAGENT_VIA} !^$ [OR] RewriteCond %{HTTP:X_FORWARDED_FOR} !^$ [OR] RewriteCond %{HTTP:PROXY_CONNECTION} !^$ [OR] RewriteCond %{HTTP:XPROXY_CONNECTION} !^$ [OR] RewriteCond %{HTTP:HTTP_PC_REMOTE_ADDR} !^$ [OR] RewriteCond %{HTTP:HTTP_CLIENT_IP} !^$ RewriteRule ^(.*)$ - [F] [/code]
Is the equivalent of this possible to implement in a rsps? I'm likely not interesting in using other sites' api's or anything that I have to purchase. If you know anything about this please comment below.
Thanks.

item.title: .htaccess and could it be used in a server?
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“noobn, post:8, topic:544109”]@AtomicInt_

Nice thread, very helpful thanks. But do http headers only get sent via browsers? Is there some way to view the details, particularly the ‘X-Forwarded-For’ header, when players are connecting via a downloadable?

@Ashi
But there are many proxies that also use a myriad of other ports, nevertheless thanks. Interesting suggestion. :~)[/quote]

There are a number of ways to determine a browsers details, user-agent is one of them. Do some Googling.

Read full topic

@Ashi

item.title: .htaccess and could it be used in a server?
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

Easier way to tell, not that I know of.

This thread may have some information you’re looking for: http://security.stackexchange.com/questions/36420/how-can-a-website-find-my-real-ip-address-while-im-behind-a-proxy

Read full topic
item.source: .htaccess and could it be used in a server?

item.title: .htaccess and could it be used in a server?
item.dc:creator: @noobn noobn
item.description:
@noobn wrote:

Isn’t there an easier way to tell a genuine IP from a proxy? I’m not interested in constantly looking for public proxies/tor exit nodes.

It’s just for security purposes. I’d like to be able to identify users who misbehave and make sure there are no continuous offenders of any server rules of conduct and so forth.

Read full topic
item.source: .htaccess and could it be used in a server?

item.title: .htaccess and could it be used in a server?
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

There are third party applications and services that have built known proxy and VPN host lists, if you can utilize them properly they can be a helpful tool for automatically blacklisting the hosts from connecting to your website/game.

I have used Black Box in the past for detecting proxies.

However, you should probably tell the user that we don’t allow connections through a proxy or other mask so they know why they cannot connect to you instead of just blacklisting them with no warning.

Also, why do you need this? It seems a little odd to need such a feature.

Read full topic
item.source: .htaccess and could it be used in a server?

item.source: .htaccess and could it be used in a server?

item.title: .htaccess and could it be used in a server?
item.dc:creator: @noobn noobn
item.description:
@noobn wrote:

Goal: block all vpn, proxy and tor traffic from accessing server/site

Could someone explain this snippet of code that I found which supposedly does the trick? And not a summary of what it does. I’d like to know what individual characters and directives mean.

RewriteEngine on
RewriteCond %{HTTP:VIA}                 !^$ [OR]
RewriteCond %{HTTP:FORWARDED}           !^$ [OR]
RewriteCond %{HTTP:USERAGENT_VIA}       !^$ [OR]
RewriteCond %{HTTP:X_FORWARDED_FOR}     !^$ [OR]
RewriteCond %{HTTP:PROXY_CONNECTION}    !^$ [OR]
RewriteCond %{HTTP:XPROXY_CONNECTION}   !^$ [OR]
RewriteCond %{HTTP:HTTP_PC_REMOTE_ADDR} !^$ [OR]
RewriteCond %{HTTP:HTTP_CLIENT_IP}      !^$
RewriteRule ^(.*)$ - [F]

Is the equivalent of this possible to implement in a rsps? I’m likely not interesting in using other sites’ api’s or anything that I have to purchase. If you know anything about this please comment below.

Thanks.

Read full topic
